title: 107_hr3244
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Spirit of America Commemorative Coin Act of 2001". The Congress acknowledges the tragic events of September 11, 2001, where over 6,000 lives were lost in terrorist attacks. Emergency personnel responded heroically, and the nation united in support of the victims and their families. The civilized world stands against such cowardly acts of terrorism. The minting of coins in commemoration of the Spirit of America pays tribute to the heroes of the 9/11 attacks and the united people's belief in freedom, justice, and democracy. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $50 gold coins weighing 1 ounce with 91.67% gold content, $1 silver coins weighing 26.73 grams with 90% silver content, and half dollar clad coins. The Secretary will mint half dollar clad coins weighing 11.34 grams with a diameter of 1.205 inches. Additionally, the Secretary will mint 50 dollar gold coins equal to the number of innocent individuals killed in the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks. The coins minted under this Act will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The Secretary can only use metals from natural deposits in the US or its territories for minting. In exigent circumstances, special treatment may be given as per specific findings by Congress. The commemorative coins serve to bring stability to the markets, maximize demand, and ensure broad private support. The Spirit of America coin program was implemented quickly after September 11, 2001, to raise funds for the victims. The Act justifies exempting coins produced under it from limitations due to existing commemorative coin programs for 2001 and 2002. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. The coins minted under this Act will commemorate the tragic events of September 11, 2001, with designs representing the Pentagon, World Trade Center, and the American flag. The coins will bear inscriptions of the date "September 11, 2001", along with words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design for the coins minted under this Act, bearing the likeness of the World Trade Center in New York City, will be selected by the Secretary after consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts. SEC. 5. STRIKING AND ISSUANCE OF COINS. SEC. 5. STRIKING AND ISSUANCE OF COINS.

(a) Quality of Coins. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated quality, except for $50 gold coins which shall be issued in proof quality.

(b) Mint Facility. Only 1 facility of the United States Mint may be used to strike any particular quality of coins, except for half dollar coins which can be struck at any number of facilities.

(c) Period for Issuance. The Secretary shall start issuing coins soon after the enactment of this Act and shall not issue any coins after 1 year. The Secretary shall not issue any coins after the 1-year period from the date of first issuance. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The Secretary shall sell coins at a price including face value, surcharges, and design costs. Bulk sales will be at a discount, and prepaid orders will also receive a discount. Gold coins may be sold despite certain restrictions. The Secretary may issue a free 50 dollar coin to the next of kin of identified individuals, but cannot sell or issue it except as specified. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES ON SALE OF COINS. The Secretary of the Treasury will add a surcharge to the sale of coins minted under the Act to cover production costs. Any excess proceeds will be given to the Office for Victims of Crime for assisting individuals injured or families of victims. The Secretary of the Treasury will add a surcharge to the sale of coins minted under the Act to cover production costs, with excess proceeds going to assist individuals injured or families of victims in the 9/11 terrorist attacks. SEC. 8. VICTIMS OF SEPTEMBER 11TH FUND. Established as the "Victims of September 11th Fund," this fund is administered by the Attorney General through the Office for Victims of Crime. It consists of transferred amounts and is used to assist individuals injured or killed in the 9/11 attacks, with no administrative costs deducted from the assistance provided. The Fund is administered by the Attorney General and assists individuals affected by the 9/11 attacks. Amounts in the Fund are invested according to regulations, and any interest or proceeds are added to the Fund. Assistance provided under subsection (c) is not considered collateral source compensation. Appropriations are authorized for the Attorney General to carry out this section.
